column4: I've got a mate, running Ubuntu. He's not very computer literate. I'd like to send him a program to run, which is not packaged for Ubuntu (or Debian). It's currently available as source. What's the best way for me to get the program to him so that he can easily install it? Should I build a deb? (Clicking debs from Nautilus doesn't seem to work on my warty install.)
what program is it?
in this case it's comical (http://comical.sourceforge.net/), but I'm interested in a more general solution.
use a web search engine to see if anyone has made unofficial debs
otherwise your best bet is to compile and install it in /usr/local

yep, that's what *I'd* do, but I don't want to have to talk him through the ./configure, make, make install dance if I can avoid it; I'd rather either ship him a compiled binary or some previously existing thing which does the compilation etc for him. I did think about building my own .deb, but I'm not great at building debs.
apt has always been intelligent about {up,down}grades
the user, however, usually isn't.
ha. Well put.
both warty and hoary {will} ship with a 2.6 kernel
yep. So does /etc/init.d/modutils requiring /proc/ksyms, which isn't in 2.6 kernels, count as a bug?
it requires /proc/ksyms? It doesn't do so on my Warty or Hoary boxes.
line 9 in my /etc/init.d/modutils: [ -f /proc/ksyms ]  || exit 0
no, it's not a bug, why?
what if you had to boot a 2.4 kernel on that box?
ok, but that means that modules listed in /etc/modules don't get loaded if you boot a 2.6 kernel.
they do get loaded.
what loads them? I'm puzzled.
I have apm in /etc/modules, and it's not loaded when the machine boots. "modprobe apm" works fine when I do it myself, though.
look in /etc/init.d/module-init-tools
no such file. hm. apt-get --reinstall install module-init-tools hasn't recreated it, either. How can I get it back? It's in dpg --listfiles module-init-tools.
unpack the deb using dpkg-deb, then copy it over manually
that should be OK. Cheers for the help.
np
